title: [ENH] rename "kernel based" to "convolution based" algorithms, and reserve "kernel based" for actual kernel based algos in the sense of kernel methods
body:
Currently, we have a category for time series classifiers/regressors which is called "kernel based".

I think this is a potentially misleading misnomer, since those algorithms aren't actually "kernel methods" in the sense that is common in machine learning and AI, refer for instance to the book "learning with kernels" by Schoelkopf and Smola.

Most people in the data science, ML, AI space would think of the term "kernel methods" as a term describing methods that use kernels in the sense of using kernels associated to reproducing kernel Hilbert spaces (RKHS), and, more specifically, algorithms that make use of scalar product evaluates in RKHS which can easily be replaced by kernel function evaluations.

The common definition of a "kernel methods" is of one that internally uses evaluates of reproducing kernel functions.
Examples: kernel support vector machine, kernel k-means, kernel knn, kernel PCA

I am aware that the word kernel has other common meanings, such as:

* the [kernel of a map, i.e., the pre-image of zero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kernel_(algebra)). Unrelated to this.
* a [convolution kernel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kernel_(image_processing)), as commonly used in signal and image processing
* an [integral kernel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integral_kernel), which is related to both RKHS kernels and convolution kernels

The subtle thing is: Rocket uses *convolution* kernels but not RKHS kernels, i.e., it does not use evaluates of kernel functions as would be characteristic for "kernel methods" in that sense.

Whereas, ML users would typically expect to be able to specify the kernel function in a "kernel based method".

I hence propose to rename the category from the ambiguous (and potentially misleading) "kernel based" category to "convolution based", and reserve the category "kernel based" to methods that take RKHS kernels as hyper-parameters.
